factoid: The woman exclaimed, "O God, O God! What does it mean?"
The woman exclaimed, "To bed then, if it must be!"
The woman slammed the casement.
Prince Andrew thought, "For the woman I might as well not exist!"
Prince Andrew listened to the woman's voice.
Prince Andrew expected that the woman might say something about him.
Prince Andrew feared that the woman might say something about him.
Prince Andrew thought, "There she is again!"
Prince Andrew thought, "As if it were on purpose."
Prince Andrew experienced an unexpected turmoil of youthful thoughts and hopes in his soul.
Prince Andrew could not explain his condition to himself.
Prince Andrew lay down and fell asleep at once.
Prince Andrew took leave of the count.
Prince Andrew did not wait for the ladies to appear.
Prince Andrew set off for home.
It was the beginning of June.
Prince Andrew drove into the birch forest on his return journey.
The gnarled old oak made a strange and memorable impression on Prince Andrew.
In the forest the harness bells sounded more muffled than six weeks before.
The forest was thick, shady, and dense.
The young firs dotted about in the forest did not jar on the general beauty.
The young firs were delicately green with fluffy young shoots.
The whole day had been hot.
A storm was gathering somewhere.
A small cloud scattered some raindrops lightly.
The raindrops sprinkled the road and the sappy leaves.
The left side of the forest was dark in the shade.
The right side of the forest glittered in the sunlight.
The right side of the forest was wet and shiny.
The right side of the forest scarcely swayed by the breeze.
Everything in the forest was in blossom.
The nightingales trilled.
The nightingales' voices reverberated near and far away.
Prince Andrew thought, "Yes, here in this forest was that oak with which I agreed."
Prince Andrew wondered, "But where is it?"
Prince Andrew gazed at the left side of the road.
Prince Andrew looked with admiration at the very oak he sought.
The old oak was transfigured.
The old oak spread a canopy of sappy dark‑green foliage.
The old oak stood rapt and slightly trembling in the rays of the evening sun.
The old oak had no gnarled fingers.
The old oak had no old scars.
The old oak had no old doubts and sorrows in evidence.
The old oak had leaves sprouting through the hard century‑old bark.
The old oak had leaves even where there were no twigs.
Prince Andrew thought, "Yes, it is the same oak."
Prince Andrew was seized by an unreasoning springtime feeling of joy and renewal.
The best moments of Prince Andrew's life rose to his memory.
Austerlitz was a moment in Prince Andrew's life.
The lofty heavens were present at Austerlitz.
Prince Andrew's wife's dead reproachful face was a moment in his life.
Pierre at the ferry was a moment in Prince Andrew's life.
The girl thrilled by the beauty of the night was a moment in Prince Andrew's life.
That night itself was a moment in Prince Andrew's life.
The moon was a moment in Prince Andrew's life.
Prince Andrew decided that life is not over at thirty‑one.
Prince Andrew decided that it is not enough for him to know what he has in him.
Prince Andrew decided that everyone must know what he has in him.
Prince Andrew decided that Pierre must know him.
Prince Andrew decided that the young girl who wanted to fly away into the sky must know him.
Prince Andrew decided that everyone must know him.
Prince Andrew decided that his life may not be lived for himself alone.
Prince Andrew decided that others live apart from his life.
Prince Andrew decided that his life may be reflected in others.
Prince Andrew decided that he and others may live in harmony.
